Award.AwardTitle: A study of the dynamics of drop impact: Impact forces, pressure and shear stress distributions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
From raindrops battering on a windshield to coffee splashing on a table, drop impact is ubiquitous in our daily life and relevant to many important natural and industrial processes. Although the phenomenon has been studied for many decades, the understanding of drop impact is still far from complete due to the complexity associated with typical fast impact processes. Significant progress has been made on drop impact in recent years using high-speed photographic techniques. Relying on direct imaging, most experiments focused on the kinematics of drop impact, i.e., the shape of impacting drops. Few studies have probed the dynamic properties of drop impact such as its impact force, pressure and shear stress. These dynamic quantities lead to the most important outcome of an impact event and affect a wide range of phenomena, including soil erosion, impact-induced wear/damage and the survival of living organisms exposed to the elements. The goal of this research is to conduct a systematic study on mapping the dynamic aspects of drop impact under different conditions. The research will develop a new experimental technique, 3D high-speed stress microscopy, to measure the impact force, pressure, and shear stress of drop impact with high spatial and temporal resolutions. The project will provide a fundamental understanding of the dynamics of drop impact in unexplored regimes and a practical guideline to control impact forces and mitigate impact-induced damage on solid substrates. The project will also provide a unique opportunity to introduce frontier research in undergraduate curriculum and forge collaborations with coating companies.

By combining traction force microscopy with high-speed photography, the research will construct a 3D high-speed stress microscope to measure the temporal variation of pressure and shear stress distributions beneath an impacting drop during a fast impact process. With the new technique, the project will verify previous theoretical predictions, including the singular dynamics of off-center pressures, the scaling relation of drag forces, and the propagation of boundary layers in spreading drops. As such, the study will reveal the dynamics of drop impact in spatiotemporal regimes, inaccessible to conventional kinematic measurements. Moreover, the research will examine the influence of different surface properties such as stiffness, wettability, and micro-textures on the stress distributions. The study aims to seek optimal surface designs, which can substantially reduce impact-induced wear and damage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The impact of a liquid drop on a solid surface is a common yet complex phenomenon, playing a vital role in numerous natural and industrial processes—from soil erosion and aerosol dispersion to inkjet printing and spray coating. Understanding the dynamics of drop impact is both fundamentally intriguing and practically significant. On a fundamental level, drop impact serves as a key model for examining the intricate interplay of forces that govern fluid flow across various length and time scales. Insights from such studies can significantly enhance our understanding of fluid dynamics. Practically, controlling drop impact outcomes is essential for optimizing industrial coating and printing techniques. Consequently, drop impact has been one of the most extensively studied topics in fluid dynamics, with research dating back over a century to Worthington's pioneering work.

Among the various aspects of drop impact, its dynamical features—specifically, the impact force and stress of the drops—have been less explored due to the lack of suitable experimental techniques. In this project, we developed new methods to measure the temporal evolution of impact forces, as well as the pressure and shear stress distributions beneath impacting drops. We applied these techniques to study the impact of both Newtonian and non-Newtonian drops and further extended our research to investigate the scaling relation of the maximum spreading of impacting drops.

This project yielded three significant results. First, we developed a novel method called high-speed stress microscopy to capture the rapid evolution of pressure and shear stress distributions beneath millimeter-sized drops at varying impact velocities. Our findings revealed that the maximum pressure and shear stress propagate along with the contact line at a speed exceeding the speed of sound in the impacted surface during the early stages of impact. This leads to the formation of a shock wave, causing considerable surface wear. Second, we devised a numerical method to simulate the impact of non-Newtonian shear-thinning and shear-thickening drops. By integrating these simulations with experimental data on different non-Newtonian fluids, we investigated how the maximum impact forces depend on the rheological properties of these fluids. Notably, we established a correlation between the relaxation time of the fluids and the maximum impact force. Finally, we explored the maximum spreading behavior of both Newtonian and non-Newtonian drops. Our results challenge the established understanding of how the maximum spreading depends on various impact parameters, revealing a new regime with previously overlooked scaling laws. Overall, our findings significantly advance the understanding of drop impact dynamics and introduce a powerful tool for measuring previously unexplored aspects of this phenomenon. Additionally, our work offers valuable insights for controlling drop impact outcomes, such as the extent of spreading and impact-induced damage and wear.

Our work has resulted in two publications in highly-ranked journals: one in Nature Communications and the other in the Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics. Additionally, we are preparing two more manuscripts to report findings from the latter stages of the project. A graduate student supported by this project has successfully completed their Ph.D., with their thesis published. The grant also supported five presentations at national and international conferences, and the PI delivered several seminars on the topic at various institutions. These activities have been instrumental in disseminating our results within both academic and industrial communities. Particularly, our work has garnered significant interest from the coating industry, fostering opportunities for future collaborations. Finally, the grant has also supported the PI's outreach efforts. Our results have been featured by several news outlets, including an interview on WTIP 90.7 North Shore Community Radio, helping to raise public awareness of science and engineering. The PI also mentored the University of Minnesota's Energy Club and organized science demonstrations for pre-K children at the University of Minnesota Child Development Center, further promoting interest in research among the general public.
